summary: A letter from defense attorney Laura A. Menninger to the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding expert witness testimony in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The letter addresses disclosure requirements for a defense expert, Mr. , who will testify about computer metadata and its interpretation, and objects to the government's untimely supplemental notice for their expert Stephen Flatley.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing the defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, objecting to the government's untimely expert disclosure and outlining the defense's planned metadata testimony.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case referenced (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell), the subject of the legal proceedings.

persons.name: Stephen Flatley
persons.context: An expert for the government; the defense objects to a supplemental notice provided for him as untimely.

persons.name: Mr.
persons.context: A defense expert (name redacted) who will testify about the meaning and origins of computer metadata, explaining that metadata values do not necessarily indicate authorship or interaction with documents.

connections.description: Menninger is a defense attorney writing on behalf of the defense in Maxwell's criminal case.
Menninger is disclosing and managing the expert testimony of Mr.  for the defense.
Both are expert witnesses in the same case, with Flatley for the prosecution and Mr.  for the defense, potentially offering rebuttal testimony.

events.title: Court Order for Expert Disclosure Supplement
events.description: The court issued an order directing a supplement to the disclosure for a defense expert witness.

events.title: Government's Original Expert Disclosure
events.description: The government provided its original disclosure for expert Stephen Flatley.

events.title: Government's Untimely Supplemental Notice
events.description: The government provided a supplemental notice for expert Stephen Flatley, which the defense deems untimely and intends to object to at trial.

keyFacts: The defense plans to have an expert, Mr. , testify that computer metadata fields like 'Authors' or 'Last saved by' do not necessarily prove a person authored or interacted with a document.
The defense objects to the government's untimely supplemental notice for their expert Stephen Flatley and intends to block any new opinions from him at trial.
The defense reserves the right to disclose specific metadata testimony from their expert in response to exhibits introduced by the government during its case.
A key figure's name (the defense expert) is redacted in the document, indicated as 'Mr. '.
